content:
The formulas that your friend has used are steps to calculate the Leaf Area Index (LAI) using the LAI-2000 instrument. The LAI-2000 uses a sensor to measure the amount of light that is transmitted through a leaf canopy at different angles, and from that, it calculates the LAI.

1. =EXP(AVERAGE(LN(D11),LN(D22)))
This formula is taking the average of the natural logarithm (LN) of the two reference measurements (A1 and A2) and then raises e (the base of the natural logarithm, approximately 2.718) to the power of that average value.
This is done to calculate the average transmittance above the canopy.
2. =-LN(K12)
This formula is taking the natural logarithm of the transmittance value measured under the canopy and negating the value. This is because the LAI is calculated as the negative natural logarithm of the transmittance.
3. =R12/0.5\*COS(Y$10)
In this formula, R12 is the result obtained from step 2, 0.5 is a constant used to correct for the sensor's field of view, and COS(Y$10) is the cosine of the angle of measurement. This is done to correct for the difference in path length of light through the canopy at different angles.

Finally, your friend can plot the results as a function of angle and compare the differences between the two sets of measurements. The fact that the values are not the same for all angles indicate that the leaf angles distribution is not completely random, and the difference between the two sets of measurements indicate the amount of light that is blocked by the canopy.
